title: Simple Whole Wheat Bread Recipe
description: This honey whole wheat bread recipe is proof that wonderful flavor, texture, and aroma can be had if you just follow a straightforward game plan.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Bread Yeast Bread Recipes Whole Grain Bread Recipes Wheat Bread Simple Whole Wheat Bread 4.8 (2,577) 2,048 Reviews 527 Photos A great-tasting whole wheat bread recipe, easy to make with simple ingredients. Submitted by Nita Crabb Updated on April 10, 2024 Save Rate Print Share Add Photo 527 527 527 527 Prep Time: 25 mins Cook Time: 25 mins Additional Time: 2 hrs Total Time: 2 hrs 50 mins Servings: 36 Yield: 3 loaves Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 36 servings 3 cups warm water (110 degrees F/45 degrees C) 2 (.25 ounce) packages active dry yeast ⅔ cup honey, divided 5 cups bread flour 5 tablespoons butter, melted, divided 1 tablespoon salt 4 cups whole wheat flour, or more as needed Directions Gather all ingredients. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Mix warm water, yeast, and 1/3 cup honey in a large bowl to dissolve. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Add 5 cups bread flour, and stir to combine. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Let sit for 30 minutes, or until big and bubbly. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Mix in 3 tablespoons melted butter, remaining 1/3 cup honey, and salt. Stir in 2 cups whole wheat flour. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Transfer dough to a floured work surface and gradually knead in remaining 2 cups whole wheat flour. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Knead until dough starts to pull away from the work surface, adding more whole wheat flour if necessary; dough should be a bit tacky to the touch, but not too sticky. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Place in a greased bowl, turning once to coat the surface of the dough. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Cover with a dish towel and let rise in a warm place until doubled, 45 minutes to 1 hour. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Grease three 9x5-inch loaf pans. Punch down the dough, and divide it into 3 loaves. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Place in the prepared loaf pans, and allow to rise until dough has topped the pans by one inch, another 45 minutes to 1 hour. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Meanwhile, preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Bake the risen loaves in the preheated oven until golden brown for 25 to 30 minutes, do not overbake. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Lightly brush the tops of the loaves with remaining 2 tablespoons melted butter when done to prevent crust from getting hard. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Cool completely. Enjoy! Dotdash Meredith Food Studios I Made It Print 4,136 home cooks made it! Nutrition Facts (per serving) 134 Calories 2g Fat 26g Carbs 4g Protein Show Full Nutrition Label Hide Full Nutrition Label Nutrition Facts Servings Per Recipe 36 Calories 134 % Daily Value * Total Fat 2g 3% Saturated Fat 1g 6% Cholesterol 4mg 1% Sodium 207mg 9% Total Carbohydrate 26g 9% Dietary Fiber 2g 7% Total Sugars 5g Protein 4g 8% Calcium 8mg 1% Iron 1mg 7% Potassium 76mg 2% * Percent Daily Values are based on a 2,000 calorie diet. Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. (-) Information is not currently available for this nutrient. If you are following a medically restrictive diet, please consult your doctor or registered dietitian before preparing this recipe for personal consumption. Add Your Photo Photos of Simple Whole Wheat Bread 01 of 527 Photo by  Dotdash Meredith Food Studios 02 of 527 Photo by  Leslie Hamm Whitson 02/17/2025 A keeper! Just the thought of making bread was daunting. This recipe was easy and the finished product tasted almost as good as my sweet, little, grandmother's wheat bread. I divided the dough to make only two loaves like many of the other reviewers. It's amazing! 03 of 527 Photo by  Barb Ruth 01/26/2025 A keeper! Great flavors Easy to follow I’ve been looking for a yeast honey wheat bread and came across this one. I’ve been making wheat sourdough and it just wasn’t enough of a wheat taste. I am so glad I found this. It’s fantastic. The only thing I did differently is divide the dough into three and then degassed it. It’s too large for me to degass in its entirety. It cooked perfectly in my cast iron bread pans and I’m not sure if/how we’ll ever go back to store bought bread. This recipe is a keeper! Great crust and a beautiful crumb. 04 of 527 Photo by  Evelyn Miller 01/03/2025 Might try again It was an easy recipe. Back in 1980;s I use to make all my breads. I only mixed the yeast, warm water, honey first then added some of the flour.I think my way worked better than this Allrecipes recipe. 05 of 527 Photo by  SteadyFrog3228 02/27/2024 A keeper! Great flavors Easy to follow Worth the effort Ignore the photos and video on this page and just follow the instructions for a wonderful honey-wheat loaf! I used a stand mixer to knead for about 10 minutes. Bake to 190 degrees F, or a bit over. 06 of 527 Photo by  Shannon 01/22/2024 My first try at making loaf bread and this was PHENOMENAL! I chose to make 2 larger loaves verses the 3 smaller loaves. Still only needed about 30 min in the oven. Highly recommend this recipe! 07 of 527 Photo by  TrendySalad1190 12/22/2023 I made this bread twice, once with sesame seeds and once without. Each turned out great. I used the entire recipe but only made two 9 x 5 loaves instead of three and baked them for 32 minutes at 350. 08 of 527 Photo by  SoapyTaco6977 05/14/2023 I didn’t have bread flour so used whole wheat mostly and some white flour for rolling. They look great and I am not a bread maker! I did add some cardamom, nutmeg and allspice for fun. Otherwise I followed the recipe with I believe 1 c less flour total. Easy! Tastes a bit bitter. Not sure why. Consistency is excellent. 09 of 527 Photo by  Kasheena Katie Dale Smith 04/21/2023 10 of 527 Photo by  TidyRoe8532 04/05/2023 I tried this recipe using molasses instead of honey, because I was out of honey. It seemed like far too much flour at first, but after working the dough for some time it came together nicely. End result was very good. Thanks for sharing your recipe. 1 2 3 4 5 Next You’ll Also Love Honey Wheat Bread I 775 Ratings Fabulous Homemade Bread 623 Ratings Buttermilk Honey Wheat Bread 287 Ratings Healthier Amish Friendship Bread Starter 1 Rating Whole Wheat Zucchini Herb Bread 61 Ratings Chef John's Whole Wheat Ciabatta 22 Ratings High Fiber Bread 11 Ratings Honey Wheat Bread II 402 Ratings Oat Whole Wheat Bread 63 Ratings Bread Machine Pumpernickel Bread 235 Ratings Kid-Friendly Wheat Bread 99 Ratings Tabitha's Homemade Wheat Bread 16 Ratings Whole Wheat Honey Bread 930 Ratings Fabulous Homemade Bread for the Food Processor 25 Ratings Dee's Health Bread 173 Ratings Steakhouse Wheat Bread for the Bread Machine 444 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: Nita Crabb
instructions: Gather all ingredients. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Mix warm water, yeast, and 1/3 cup honey in a large bowl to dissolve. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Knead until dough starts to pull away from the work surface, adding more whole wheat flour if necessary; dough should be a bit tacky to the touch, but not too sticky. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Place in a greased bowl, turning once to coat the surface of the dough. Punch down the dough, and divide it into 3 loaves.
